key_points: Approximately 200,000 live animals are trapped in the Suez Canal, facing likely death due to being stuck behind the 'Ever Given' cargo vessel.
Gabrile Pﾄブn, the EU director for Animals International, calls this the worst maritime animal welfare tragedy in history.
The animals are running out of feed and water, with 130,000 of them originating from Romania.
EU law mandates ships carrying live animals to have 25% more food than planned, but this rule is often not followed.
Romanian authority ANSVSA claims there is enough food and water for a few days, but live animal exports have been suspended.
Pﾄブn criticizes the lack of transparency and regulation, noting that mortality rates on these ships are not reported due to EU legislation.
Romania has been criticized by the European Commission for its poor practices in live animal exports.
In the past, Romania has failed to meet transport conditions, leading to thousands of animal deaths.
Pﾄブn suggests exporting meat rather than live animals as a more humane and profitable alternative.
Despite the recognition of benefits in exporting processed meat, Romania continues live animal exports.
